name: Oak Island Treasure Mystery #1 Quiz | World | 10 Questions

questions.correct: Off the coast of Eastern Canada
options: Off the coast of Western Canada
Off the coast of Eastern Mexico
Off the coast of Western Mexico
questions.explanation:
Off the coast of Eastern Canada.

	It's a small island in the general vicinity of Nova Scotia.

questions.text: According to the most popular story, who made the discovery that something may have been buried in Oak Island?
questions.explanation:
Schoolboys.

	Three schoolboys apparently rowed across from the mainland and discovered evidence that something had been buried. That's when the fun - and the legend - began.

questions.text: Around which year do most stories say that the first excavations in search of "treasure" were made at Oak Island?
questions.explanation:
1800.

	The schoolboys (in the preceding question) made the discovery just prior to 1800.

questions.text: What 'booby trap' was (and still is) a major impediment to excavating the pit?
questions.explanation:
Frequent Flooding.

	Whenever excavation seems to be making progress, the pit floods. What 'primitive' genius of so long ago was able to devise an underwater system that would confound excavation attempts for centuries?

questions.text: What future US president visited Oak Island on a 'dig'?
questions.explanation:
Franklin D Roosevelt.

	Young (college student) FDR was one of those who explored the mystery.

questions.text: One early theory speculated that pirate gold was buried there. What pirate's name most is most often cited in connection with this theory?
questions.explanation:
Captain Kidd.

	Kidd worked his piracy off the northeast coast of the U.S. in the latter part of the 18th century. So, when one thinks of buried pirate treasure ...

questions.text: What evidence supports the idea that the pit is not a natural phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
All of these.

	Coconut fiber was found in the pit: it is not indigenous to the island. Symbols were found encoded on stones (and on {parchment);} the message (once translated) tells of a treasure buried below. Drilling has occasionally recovered an earring or some such piece of jewelry.

questions.text: What author is most frequently associated with the mystery?
questions.explanation:
Shakespeare.

	Legend has it that proof that the original manuscripts of William Shakespeare's plays are buried there, proving that someone other than Shakespeare (usually Francis Bacon) was the real author.

questions.text: What theories exist as to the content of the pit?
questions.explanation:
All of these.

	Pirate gold, of course. Manuscripts regarding Shakespeare - see comment to preceding question. Also, it is speculated that information regarding 'secret organizations' (Freemasons, Rosicrucians, Knights Templar, etc.) may be buried there.

questions.text: What caused the single biggest loss of life in the treasure hunt?
questions.explanation:
Noxious fumes.

	Several members of a family that was attempting to excavate the pit apparently succumbed to noxious fumes (carbon dioxide or gasoline) and fell into the pit.
